articles.title: About this site
articles.contents:
We created this website using the R package {distill} (check the distillery for other websites
created in the same way).
This is a very simple system to create a very simple website for
those who know R and markdown.
We are fully aware that R is not the best tool for creating a proper
website, but we only do a few things properly besides data analyses.
We also don‚Äôt have the man power or the desire to spend much time
working on our website.

articles.title: Consulting
articles.description: We offer training and consulting about R, statistics, data visualisation and anything else we know for everyone.
articles.contents:
Outside academia
We do a fair a bit of training and consulting outside academia. We do
this because for two main reasons:
we rely on some of our consulting fees to finance our research
activities.
we are well aware that conservation involves many actors that do not
belong to universities or public research institutes.
If you are interested, please contact us.
Topics
Our technical expertise lies in R programming (from
introduction to R package development), data manipulation (in
R), data visualisation (with or without R) and data
analysis (in particular: traditional statistical tests, generalised
linear models, mixed models, spatial analyses, survival analyses, random
forests, individual-based simulations).
Yet, as long as we feel competent enough to be useful, we are happy
to offer consulting or training on any topic.
We always highly customise the content of training sessions to match
the task and requirement of the client.
Here are some representative examples of the training &
consulting we are currently providing:
workshop for data visualisation organised by XXX.
development of R packages and advanced R training for all data
scientists at Factworks, a
market research and analytic company.
support in statistical analyses for the Nature and Biodiversity
Conservation Union in Germany (NABU),
the World Wildlife Foundation (WWF) and the conservation NGO
rewild.
Just write to us and
we will happily put you in contact with people we worked with for you to
get direct feedback on how they perceived our work.
Pricing and the Robin Hood model
Our pricing depends on the content, as well as on the number and
identity of both the members from our team and the client(s).
If the work is for a for profit company, our default protocol is to
request the company to either pay our hosting institution (the IZW) or to pay one of
the non-profit foundations we work with. In both cases, the money is
used by us as a third party support to our research. We call this the
Robin Hood model, but this is hardly stealing: we remain very
competitive compared to fees required by equally qualified free lancers
out there.
If the work is related to wildlife conservation or other activities
we consider as highly beneficial to society as a whole, we try to be as
cheap as we can.
For a quote, please contact us.
Availability
Our availability is what constrains the amount of consulting we do.
We can arrange regular short consultations or block consulting for
duration of up to 10 days, but we cannot offer more. If you need more,
just contact us and we
will attempt to connect you to former members of the group and other
people we know and trust who have become free lancers.
Within academia
We do not consult within academia with the exception of our local
colleagues and students, as well as users of the methods we develop.
Instead, we favour genuine collaborations where our role is not
limited to performing the data analysis of someone else project.
If you are interested, please contact us.
We also teach both at the IZW and at the FU (see teaching for details).

articles.title: DZG's who's who
articles.contents:
Current members
Alexandre
Courtiolüá´üá∑ (member since 2011)
perso, 
R. Senior researcher, lecturer. Initially trained as an evolutionary
biologist with a solid formation in applied statistics, Alex has adopted
ecology and demography after his PhD. He is mostly interested in humans,
wild mammals and birds. His favorite research projects are those
revealing unexpected outcomes. His focus is on questions related to life
history and behaviour, but he is always open to new exciting
collaborations. He likes programming and teaching R.
Liam Baileyüá¶üá∫ (member
since 2018) .
Postdoc. SHORT 3rd PERSON DESCRIPTION TODO.
Past members
Colin
Vullioudüá®üá≠ (20XX-20XX) came to us after getting fed up with social
science research, learned R with us, turned social behavior into
algorithms and left as a full fledged data scientist currently working
as a free lancer in Berlin, Germany. He also created the R package
{torpor} and contributed to {hyenaR}.
Elisa
DonatiüáÆüáπ (2020) came to programs virtual hyenas and to work our R
package {hyneaR} between a master on lizards and an upcoming PhD student
in Italy.
Ian Rickardüá¨üáß
(20XX) came for a sabbatical from Durham University to study how
twinning connects to fertility in humans, then switched career to become
a data scientist for the ministry of justice in the UK.
Louise Chevalierüá´üá∑ (20XX) came for a few months during her PhD to
do something else for a while. She worked with us on adding genetics to
a simulation model about hyenas. Now a circus artist in France.
Robert
Schwiegerüá©üá™ (20XX) came to do maths for fun on inference problems
about mate choice before doing a PhD in mathematics. Now working at CENTOGENE in Berlin,
Germany.
Camille
Martinezüá´üá∑ (200X) did a joint-internship here and in Montpellier
developing stats methods to draw inference using simulation before
starting her PhD. Currently doing a postdoc in Grenoble,
France.
Lo√Øc Etienneüá´üá∑ (20XX) did his PhD with us doing modelling about
the evolution of mutual mate choice. Now a musician in France.
Friends
Not quite members, not quite collaborators, but very close to us all
the same!
Ilja Heckmannüá∞üáøüá©üá™ is a biologist colleague turned full time
python programmer and Linux admin from whom we never stop
learning.
Matthias
Gallipaudüá´üá∑ is a long standing idea bouncer for the DZG, currently
data scientist based in Zurich, Switzerland.
Zimai Liüá®üá≥
worked quite a bit with us on our R package {hyneaR} while doing an
internship with colleagues.
Main collaborators
Fran√ßois
Roussetüá´üá∑, theoretical biologist at the Institut des Science de l‚ÄôEvolution in
Montpellier, France, turned hardcore statistician, author of R
package {spaMM} without which we could not do half the work we
do.
Oliver
H√∂nerüá®üá≠üáßüá∑, PI behind the hyena
project, behavioral ecologist and field biologist turning anything
hyena related into high quality datasets. Based in the department of
Evolutionary Ecology at the IZW.
Viktoriia
Radchuküá∫üá¶, individual-based modeler and big collaborative
meta-analysis producer, like us she flourishes at the interface between
field and theory. She is a key member of the department Ecological Dynamics at
the IZW.
Stephanie
Kramer-Schadtüá©üá™, head of the excellent department Ecological Dynamics at
the IZW who is
composed, almost exclusively, of great young scientists and students
with strong quantitative skills.
Kseniia
Kravchenkoüá∫üá¶, who has freshly finished her PhD at the BatLab from the IZW. She is a batwomen
with we try to predict the future by combining physiology and climate
change.
Christian
Voigtüá©üá™, head of the department of Evolutionary Ecology at the IZW and head of the BatLab.
Virpi
Lummaaüá´üáÆ, life history data queen who has produced two of the very
best demographic datasets that exist (one on pre-industrial humans and
one on Aisan Elephants). Head of the human life history science
group and of the [Myanmar Timber Elephant Project] (https://elephant-project.science) at the University of Turku in
Finland.
Collaborators wishlist
They never worked with us, but are a very much like us, so we hope to
work with them one day: Sarah
Cubaynesüá´üá∑, Olivier
Gimenezüá´üá∑, Samuel
Pavardüá´üá∑, Fran√ßois Xavier
Dechaume-Moncharmontüá´üá∑.

articles.title: DZG
articles.description: Welcome to the website of the Data Zoo Gang!
articles.contents:
Who are we?
The Data Zoo Gang is a small team of
scientists (mostly biologists) with a slight geeky data driven take
on wildlife and humans.
We all love mammals, birds, computers and R.
We enjoy collaborating with people ‚Äì whoever they are ‚Äì as long as
they really want to discover something cool and not too obvious about
their favorite species.
We hate demonstrating the obvious, and strongly dislike low quality
datasets and proprietary software (although we sometimes use both).
What do we do?
We embrace eclecticsm and draw concepts from ecology, evolution,
demography and conservation to tackle our questions.
At the technical level, we mix statistics and programming (with an
occasional dash of mathematical modeling) to analyse data collected in
the wild so as to solve puzzles about wildlife conservation, the ecology
and evolution of life history traits, animal behaviour, as well as to
better understand various aspects of health in wildlife populations
(check out our publications for more
details).
We also create open source tools (R
packages) for researchers from these communities, teach stats, experimental design, and R
programming, and offer consulting and
training both within and outside academia.
Where are we based?
We are based at the Leibniz Institute for Zoo and Wildlife Research
in Berlin, Germany (or IZW for short). Some
of us occasionally do a little bit of field work in Tanzania as also
member of the hyena project not
to loose track with the real world.
Why are we called Data Zoo
Gang?
We call our team, the Data Zoo Gang or DZG (pronounced
‚Äúdeezeegee‚Äù) for short.
Data because that is the raw material for almost
everything we do.
Zoo because we work on animals and are also based
next to an animal
park.
Gang because there is a nicer rhythm to it than
group or team and because we are almost rebels:
we think that developing methods is a scientific activity on its own
right, which should be better recognized and funded as such.
we think that most null hypothesis testing is dull.
we show no mercy to data, flimsy ideas (no matter how established)
and computers.
one past team member unconditionally wore baseball caps and there is
also a somewhat anti-capitalist vibe within the group but remain
tolerant and professional, especially since we consult for profit
companies under a Robin Hood
model.
All the same, we love collaborating with field biologists, NGOs, or
geeks from any background.
How to join us?
If you would like to join us and are a motivated scientist with
overlapping interests, no matter your skills, origin, age, sex &
gender, please do contact
us and we will figure out the details together.

articles.title: R packages
articles.description: We maintain and are key contributors to several R packages
articles.contents:
Here we list our main contributions.
We also contribute to many other R packages, but our contributions
are not as crucial or the projects are small and experiemental. For more
details, you can check our GitHub pages:

Alexandre Courtiol
 Liam
Bailey
Open source
For natural scientists
climwin
to detect and visualise periods of climate sensitivity (climate windows)
for a given biological response. Created and maintained by Liam.
IsoriX
to build isoscapes using mixed models and infer the geographic origin of
organisms based on their isotopic ratios. Created and maintained by
Alex.
torpor to fit
thermoregulatory curves in heterothermic endotherm species, while
assigning metabolic rates to the correct physiological state. Created by
Colin, while with us.
camtrapR
to manage camera trap photographs in wildlife studies. We helped its
maintainer ‚Äì J√ºrgen Niedballa ‚Äì to set it up while he was still a PhD
student.
For all data scientists
spaMM
to efficiently fit linear models of varying complexity, including mixed
models with spatial autocorrelation. We contribute to its development
mostly by using this package a lot, debugging it and suggesting new
features. Maintained by one very close collaborator (Fran√ßois
Rousset).
ABMR6 an example
of how to implement individual-based simulation using R6. Created by
Alex, maintained by Liam.
timevarcorr to
estimate time varying correlation coefficients using non-parametric
kernel smoothing. Created and maintained by Alex.
Private (for now)
hyenaR to
manage most of the data generated by the hyena project. Created and
maintained by Liam and Alex.
HyenaPopmod to
perform individual-based simulations mimicking the hyenas followed by
the hyena project. Created and
maintained by Liam.
These packages will become open whenever we will judge them ready for
others to use.

articles.title: Publications
articles.contents:
Publications are here sorted by multiple criterion (most recent, best of, by themes, by taxonomic
groups). Just hover on top of a publication to reveal its details.
Only publications created while being part of the Data Zoo Gang are
listed here. For the full list of publications of a given team member,
please use instead:
Google Scholar: Alexandre
Courtiol, Liam D.
Bailey, Ian J.
Rickard.
ORCID: Alexandre
Courtiol, Liam D.
Bailey, Colin
Vullioud, Ian J.
Rickard, Camille
Martinez-Almoyna.
 5 most recent
Our last 5 publications are:
Dayaram et
al. (2021)
Tonnabel et al. (2021)
Kruszynski et al. (2021)
best of
Here is a short selection of publications we are particularly proud
of and which best reflect our involvement and mindset.
Radchuk et
al. (2019) is a meta-analysis quantifying
precisely the extent to which animals (mostly birds) are adapting to
changing climate.
Vullioud et
al. (2019) is an in-depth study of social
hierarchy in spotted hyenas revealing how social rank emerges from
simple behavioural rules.
Corbett
et al. (2018) is a review of the causes and
consequences of demographic transitions in humans, with an emphasis on
human health.
Lahdenper√§ et al. (2018) is a detailed study of how capture
influences survival in Asian elephants.
Courtiol
& Rousset (2017) introduces a new statistical
method for modelling the distribution of stable isotopes in the
environment.
Courtiol, Etienne, et al. (2016) is a minimal model of the
evolution of mate choice in both sexes.
by themes
We study wildlife conservation, the
ecology and evolution of life history traits, animal behaviour, as well as various aspects of health in wildlife populations. We also design methods that can be applied to study these
themes.
Wildlife conservation
Climate change
Radchuk et
al. (2019), Mumby et al. (2013a)
Habitat degradation
(including urbanisation)
